page.title: 12Farming
page.content: The area surrounding Bwlchgwyn is at an altitude of between 1150 and 1200ft This then determine the type of agriculture carried out in the locality. Most farms are smallholdings and are not generally large enough to provide families with their main source of income. Many are now owned by people who farm for fun. No crops are grown (except for trees by the Forestry Commision). Animals are kept. Cows provide butter and milk Welsh mountain sheep are mainly bred to be sold as lambs, and chicken and hens are bred for eggs or for sale. Some more unuaual breeds of animal are seen in the area. These include Jacob Sheep and Anglo-Nubian goats. The land is generally fenced rough grazing, with the moorland of the Llandegla Moors nearby.
